image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: Qantas says it will now refund COVID travel credits, while the ACCC has accused the airline of selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled.

title.children: Qantas to remove expiry date on travel credits after public backlash, while ACCC accuses airline of selling tickets to cancelled flights

image.altText: A teacher dressed in red chants at the rally.

items.synopsis: While the state government has said there will be no "muskets at dawn", negotiations with the union on Wednesday failed to resolve the deadlock, meaning more than 150 schools will close, leaving thousands of families to make alternative arrangements.

title.children: 'Parents will need to make alternative arrangements': Everything you need to know about SA's teacher strike

image.altText: An image of a car crash.

items.synopsis: Police say the man allegedly threatened a security guard at Adelaide's Keswick Barracks before stealing a car and crashing it into a Glenelg East bus stop.

title.children: Man charged after allegedly threatening guard, before stealing his car

image.altText: A view of the Liddell coal-fired power plant from across a lake, with swans in the foreground

items.synopsis: Much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems over the next decade, and as soon as this summer, without rapid investment in both electricity generation and transmission.

title.children: 'Imminent and urgent investment' required as national energy grid faces reliability fears ahead of hot summer

image.altText: An aerial photo of the snowy mountain hydro-electric complex at dusk.

items.synopsis: The government reveals planned expansions to the Snowy Hydro have suffered an incredible $10 billion blowout over price estimates given by former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull six years ago.

title.children: Snowy Hydro expansion hits reset button as costs blow out to $12 billion

image.altText: A man with a moustache in front of a party tent.

items.synopsis: The Queensland Supreme Court heard Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden lived at home in what was a "dysfunctional, toxic relationship".

title.children: Gold Coast councillor charged with murdering his stepfather released on bail after urgent hearing

image.altText: Anthony Albanese with his hands up.

items.synopsis: With South Australia and Tasmania considered the key states in contest in the Voice to Parliament referendum, the prime minister hits Hobart after his visit to SA yesterday to announce the date of the referendum.

title.children: 'Convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes': Albanese spruiks Voice in Hobart on first full campaign day

image.altText: Gloved hands hold a selection of vapes above a bin of multi-coloured objects.

items.synopsis: A state school on Queensland's Gold Coast turns away from its hardline stance on vaping, in favour of an educational approach that's now being shared with other schools.

title.children: This school abandoned automatic suspensions for vaping. Here's what happened

image.altText: A woman with brown hair holding a drink.

items.synopsis: Human remains which were found beside a busy highway in Goulburn have been identified as a Sydney woman who was murdered by her former boyfriend.

title.children: Human remains found by busy highway confirmed to be those of murdered Sydney woman

image.altText: Jim Chalmers speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: Qantas has scrapped the expiry date on its COVID travel credits. Meanwhile, the competition watchdog has launched legal action against the airline for allegedly selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled. Follow live.

title.children: Treasurer says allegations Qantas sold tickets for cancelled flights 'deeply concerning', ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Energy Program Director at the Grattan Institute, Tony Wood, has reiterated the urgent warning from the Australian Energy Market Operator that more investment is needed in renewables to ensure there is suitable supply to meet rising demand in the coming warmer months. He told News Breakfast that the language used by AEMO in its outlook report has never been quite this strong before, which indicates just how urgent the need to build renewable energy projects and the transmission to connect them sooner rather than later. Mr Wood also believes changes need to be made to the planning and approvals process that is often the culprit for delaying these projects. "We can't afford to muck around here," he said. You can watch his full chat with News Breakfast's Madeleine Morris below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy expert says 'we can't afford to muck around' with ensuring energy reliability

He told

that the language used by AEMO in its outlook report has never been quite this strong before, which indicates just how urgent the need to
build renewable energy projects and the transmission to connect them
sooner rather than later.
Mr Wood also believes changes need to be made to the
planning and approvals process
that is often the culprit for delaying these projects.
"We can't afford to muck around here," he said.
You can watch his full chat with
News Breakfast's Madeleine Morris
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier this morning we reported on the energy market operator warning that much of the national power grid is facing substantial reliability problems in the coming 10 years. So, how much of our energy needs are being met by renewable sources? Daniel Westerman, who is the boss of the Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO), told ABC's AM program it fluctuates. "In fact in the National Electricity Market, we've experienced times of up to 68% of our power fed by renewable energy. "On average, though, throughout the year, it's about a third. The remaining two thirds ... is powered by these old coal fired power stations. "That really does signal the transition that over the next decade, we expect a significant number to retire to be replaced by the cheapest form of new build energy, which is renewable energy backed up by storage and connected with transmission. "The challenge for us is to make sure that those new projects get and built in a timely fashion."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How much of our energy needs are being met by renewable sources?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday we saw inflation in July fall to 4.9% — the lowest the Consumer Price Index has been in 17 months. That figure is likely to be music to ears of the RBA, which will meet to decide its next move on interest rates next Tuesday. But NAB this morning has released a note saying although inflation is coming down, price pressures are still likely to remain in the weeks ahead. That's because the monthly reading was goods heavy, while electricity prices rose by 15.7% because of rebates introduced in July, NAB market analyst Rodrigo Catril said. "Overall, the decline in the headline reading is welcome news for the RBA, but we are mindful tha t bigger price pressures are likely in August and September ," he said. "For one, these readings will be more services heavy and two, the energy/electricity jump is still working its way through. "Then one further known unknown is the impact from wage increases on services inflation, thus we remain wary of higher inflation prints over coming months .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation might be easing, but NAB warns price pressures will remain in the coming months

children.content: Yesterday we saw inflation in July fall to 4.9% — the lowest the Consumer Price Index has been in 17 months.
That figure is likely to be music to ears of the RBA, which will meet to decide its next move on interest rates next Tuesday.
But NAB this morning has released a note saying although inflation is coming down, price pressures are still likely to remain in the weeks ahead.
That's because the monthly reading was goods heavy, while electricity prices rose by 15.7% because of rebates introduced in July, NAB market analyst Rodrigo Catril said.
"Overall, the decline in the headline reading is welcome news for the RBA, but we are mindful tha
t bigger price pressures are likely in August and September
," he said.
"For one, these readings will be more services heavy and two, the energy/electricity jump is still working its way through.
"Then one further known unknown is the impact from wage increases on services inflation, thus
we remain wary of higher inflation prints over coming months

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane is visible through a window at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: The assistant treasurer says it's "entirely uncontroversial" to say that Qantas must remain profitable, as the government weathers criticism over a decision to block Qatar from adding more flights, potentially reducing airfares.

title.children: Minister walks back comments that government intervened to protect Qantas' profits

image.altText: A fox looks straight down the lens of a camera in bushland

items.synopsis: Foxes kill an astonishing 367 million mammals in Australia each year, but a study showing foxes can learn to associate prey with vomit is good news for vulnerable native species.

title.children: Could making predators puke be the key to saving Australia's wildlife?

image.altText: military vehicles are queued in a row with palm trees behind them

items.synopsis: The ADF says soldiers from the Australian Army and the Timor Leste Defence Force have been taken to Royal Darwin Hospital for treatment following the crash.

title.children: ADF Bushmaster rolls near Darwin, injuring seven Australian, East Timorese troops

image.altText: A woman leans against a tree with a Redfern sign behind her.

items.synopsis: While Yes voters in Redfern are hoping against heartache, the No campaign is targeting the undecided in Western Sydney.

title.children: How 'the Black capital of Australia' will be voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: A semi-trailer and a wrecked car covered with a tarpaulin on the side of a country road.

items.synopsis: Police say a B-double truck travelling north on the Hume collided with a car that was turning onto the freeway, killing all four people inside. The truck driver, 30, was taken to hospital with non life-threatening injuries.

title.children: Police investigate after four killed in truck, car collision in north-east Victoria

image.altText: A young and and older man both smile at the camera. They are both wearing sunglasses

items.synopsis: The father of 21-year-old Corporal Spencer Collart says his son, who was the Osprey's crew chief, put the lives of others before his own in a crash that killed three US marines.

title.children: Father of US marine killed in Osprey crash says his son 'died a hero'

image.altText: An orange moon appears behind a tower.

items.synopsis: Here are some photographs of the "blue" supermoon from around the world.

title.children: In pictures: Rare 'blue' supermoon brightens up night sky around the world

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Whichever way the referendum goes, there will be enormous ramifications for reconciliation and Indigenous advancement. There will be political consequences felt all the way to the next election — and the next six weeks absolutely matter, writes David Speers.

title.children: The differences between a referendum and an election help explain why the Voice's Yes camp is so confident

image.altText: A small white fluffy glider with prominent ears, wide eyes and a little button nose peeks out of hole in a tree at night

items.synopsis: The EPA has issued a stop-work order for timber harvesting in Tallaganda State Forest following the discovery of a deceased endangered glider.

title.children: Logging operations halted in NSW forest after dead glider discovered

image.altText: Jaymz Lester-Stevens is lying in a hospital bed, with a blue hospital gown with hands up. Medical equipment all around.

items.synopsis: Bowel cancer affects more than 15,000 Australians every year, but a rise in cases among people below the age of 50 has specialists reiterating the warning signs.

title.children: Jaymz, 26, thought he was losing weight, until a bowel cancer diagnosis changed his reality

items.synopsis: Born out of anti-government rallies during the pandemic, authorities say Germany's Reichsbürger movement is a growing threat. And it's forging ties with one of the country's biggest political parties.

title.children: Peter Fitzek says Germany doesn't exist. So he declared himself the king of a new 'kingdom'

image.altText: A woman standing in a vacant lot

items.synopsis: Multiple Victorian home owners have made complaints to the state's building authority over allegedly defective works they say have left them hundreds of thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Andrea thought she was building the home she'd retire in. $1 million later, she and her family are in a 'nightmare'

image.altText: A young white woman leaning next to a house window

items.synopsis: Ruby Callaghan has tried for six months to stop one of the world's retail giants from charging her unwanted fees. The federal government says it is looking at introducing legislation, known as "don't be a jerk laws", to help curb the issue.

title.children: Ruby tried to cancel her Amazon account in March, but got stuck in a 'subscription trap'

image.altText: Woman in blue shirt looks out sombrely between tree branches, short grey hair.

items.synopsis: Nathan Markl's body was found two weeks after he went missing, but an autopsy could not determine a cause of death. As an inquest is confirmed, his mother says she won't rest until she finds out what happened.

title.children: Two years after her son was found dead in a river, Jo is still looking for answers

image.altText: A composite of four people's faces - three women and one man.

items.synopsis: Over nine weeks of hearings, witnesses told of how a paedophile nurse was left to operate inside a children's ward, how school children were not believed, and about widescale abuse facing youth detainees in a "monster" prison.

title.children: In their words: The harrowing stories told to Tasmania's commission of inquiry

image.altText: The front of an Adelaide Prison, seen behind shrubbery

items.synopsis: A 30-year-old man who bribed a "corrupt" Yatala prison staffer to give his brother drugs in jail is sentenced to almost two years of home detention.

title.children: Man who bribed prison staffer to smuggle drugs to jailed brother sentenced to home detention

image.altText: Girl raises hand in high school classroom

items.synopsis: Friday's planned teacher strike will see 167 South Australian schools close, with teachers set to walk off the job after the government and union failed to reach a new pay agreement.

title.children: More than 150 SA public schools to close due to teacher strike

image.altText: A group of four people dressed in white PPE and wearing red vests stand around an unmarked grave.

items.synopsis: Sudan's body retrievers pick through debris in a war zone to find the bodies of those killed in the country’s months-long civil war. The task is filled with hazards and could be deadly.

title.children: Stray bullets, falling debris and the risk of infection: The deadly task to bury Sudan's dead

image.altText: Rudy Giuliiani with cameras in his face and a peacock in front of a moon

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Rudy Giuliani found liable for defamation, rare blue moon seen around the world. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A man wearing a wet purple tshirt stands in knee-deep water filled with tree branches in the street

items.synopsis: Video footage and photographs from the region around Idalia's landfall showed ocean waters washing over highways and neighbourhoods swamped by extensive flooding as residents inspected the damage.

title.children: 'All hell broke loose': Hurricane Idalia tore down houses and flooded neighbourhoods in Florida

image.altText: A man in a shirt and blazer with the top button undone gestures with his hands as he speaks.

items.synopsis: Greens housing spokesman Max Chandler-Mather says rents are going up at the fastest rate in 35 years. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Greens housing spokesman Max Chandler-Mather on rent increases. Here's what we found

image.altText: An Australian female pole vaulter pumps her fist after winning an event in Switzerland.

items.synopsis: As commuters in Zürich's central railway station cheered her on, Australia's Nina Kennedy continues her outstanding form with victory in the Diamond League meet, a week after sharing the gold medal at the world titles.

title.children: World champion Kennedy sets national pole vault record in Swiss train station

image.altText: A brightly metallic coloured beetle on the back of a white hand

items.synopsis: As insect populations decline, researchers and start-ups are looking to tech as a solution. But some fear it may create more harm.

title.children: 'Where are all the Christmas beetles?': The far-reaching effects of insect extinction

image.altText: Ron Pattenden with imagery of ACBF documentation in the background.

items.synopsis: Five former directors and officers of the failed funeral insurer Youpla are facing fines, after the corporate watchdog ASIC commenced civil proceedings over an arrangement to send the funds to a company in Vanuatu.

title.children: 'Trying to hit the stars': ASIC takes legal action against collapsed company directors

image.altText: A group of pedestrians walking along a footpath by the Yarra River on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The approaching new season follows a dry winter for the east coast, and records broke in major cities for the warmest winter on record.

title.children: Spring tipped to bring scorching temperatures and below average rainfall
